website_summaries.verdict: A good alternative for a small, lightweight bottler to keep around the house for occasional use.
pros: Grip of the bottler is large and comfortable in most hands
One handed use is possible so you can keep the cap stable on the lip of the bottle before clamping down to seal
cons: Hands will start to fatigue if trying to use the bottler for long periods of time

customer_reviews.title: Capped 24 bottles with no errors and beer was carbonated weeks later when opened.
customer_reviews.text: This bottle capper works great and is easy to use. I opened some bottles of home brew from my first batch that I put in used, sanitized bottles. The caps sealed well and the beer had good carbonation. These are the first bottles that I capped with this and I had no "duds". I tried the capper on an empty bottle initially to see how it worked. Just be sure the cap is reasonably centered on the capper (it has a magnet to hold cap) and apply pressure on handles slowly until they "give" a little as the cap is crimped on. The bottles cannot be the twist off cap type. Definitely a good purchase!
customer_reviews.author: C. J. Myers

customer_reviews.title: In order to get the caps tight (some were still ...
customer_reviews.text: In order to get the caps tight (some were still able to spin), the handles were bending and I felt as though I was going to break them. I also had to crimp and turn many times to really get them tight. I had a friend with me who has been brewing and bottling for nearly 20 years, so I trust his advice, and he said that it shouldn't be this hard. We eventually got them all tight, we thought, but once I started opening them, I found that only a third were actually sealed.
